title: MIN = GCD
statementHtml:
You are given a positive integer sequence aa of length nn. Determine if it is possible to rearrange aa such that there exists an integer ii (1≤i<n1≤i<n) satisfying

min([a1,a2,…,ai])=gcd([ai+1,ai+2,…,an]).min([a1,a2,…,ai])=gcd([ai+1,ai+2,…,an]).

Here gcd(c)gcd(c) denotes the greatest common divisor of cc, which is the maximum positive integer that divides all integers in cc.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤1052≤n≤105).

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤10181≤ai≤1018).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 105105.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output "Yes" if it is possible, and "No" otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, rearrange aa to [1,1][1,1] and let i=1i=1, then min([1])=gcd([1])min([1])=gcd([1]).

In the second test case, it can be shown that it is impossible.

In the third test case, rearrange aa to [3,2,2][3,2,2] and let i=2i=2, then min([3,2])=gcd([2])min([3,2])=gcd([2]).

In the fifth test case, rearrange aa to [3,4,5,6,9][3,4,5,6,9] and let i=3i=3, then min([3,4,5])=gcd([6,9])min([3,4,5])=gcd([6,9]).

samples.output:
Yes
No
Yes
No
Yes
Yes
Yes

tutorialHtml:
For any positive integer sequence a, we always have gcd(a)≤min(a). Let x=min(a), then x must be placed on the min([a1,a2,…,ai]) side. Thus, we can conclude that:

min([a1,a2,…,ai])=gcd([ai+1,ai+2,…,an])=x

Now, we need to select some numbers, excluding one occurrence of x, to be placed on the gcd([ai+1,ai+2,…,an]) side, ensuring that gcd([ai+1,ai+2,…,an])=x.

A greedy strategy is to place all multiples of x on the gcd side after removing one occurrence of x. This minimizes gcd while ensuring it remains a multiple of x.

Thus, we only need to check whether the gcd of the remaining multiples of x (after removing one occurrence of x) is still equal to x.

Time complexity: O(n+loga) or O(nloga) (depending on which gcd implementation you use) per test case.
